quizzes.question: An object has:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]What is an Object[/h1]

[b]O[/b]bject [b]O[/b]riented [b]P[/b]rogramming is a programming style that is intended to make thinking about programming closer to thinking about the real world.

In programming, [b]objects [/b]are independent units, and each has its own [b]identity[/b], just as objects in the real world do.
[note]An apple is an object; so is a mug. Each has its unique [b]identity[/b]. It's possible to have two mugs that look identical, but they are still separate, unique objects.[/note]

answers.text: The current state of an object

quizzes.question: An attribute describes:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Objects[/h1]

An object might contain other objects but they're still different objects. 

Objects also have [b]characteristics [/b]that are used to describe them. For example, a car can be red or blue, a mug can be full or empty, and so on. These characteristics are also called [b]attributes[/b]. An attribute describes the current [b]state [/b]of an object. 
Objects can have multiple attributes (the mug can be [b]empty[/b], [b]red [/b]and [b]large[/b]).
[note]An object's [b]state [/b]is independent of its type; a cup might be full of water, another might be empty.[/note]

quizzes.question: What are the three things that describe an object in object-oriented programming language?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Objects[/h1]

In the real world, each object [b]behaves [/b]in its own way. The car [b]moves[/b], the phone [b]rings[/b], and so on.
The same applies to objects - behavior is specific to the object's type.
[note]So, the following three dimensions describe any object in object oriented programming: [b]identity[/b], [b]attributes[/b], [b]behavior[/b].[/note]

answers.text: Objects are not always physical items
Objects are not always visible items

quizzes.question: In regard to objects, which two of the following statements are true?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Objects[/h1]

In programming, an object is [b]self-contained[/b], with its own [b]identity[/b]. It is separate from other objects.
Each object has its own [b]attributes[/b], which describe its current state. Each exhibits its own [b]behavior[/b], which demonstrates what they can do. [img id="2427" width="100%"]
In computing, objects aren't always representative of physical items. 
For example, a programming object can represent a date, a time, a bank account. A bank account is not tangible; you can't see it or touch it, but it's still a well-defined object - it has its own [b]identity[/b], [b]attributes[/b], and [b]behavior[/b].
[note]Tap [b]Continue [/b]to dive right into Object Oriented Programming ([b]OOP[/b]) with C++![/note]
